Dorothea Dix

Activities Towards the End of Her Life

Dorothea Dix participated in other activities beyond her endorsement of reforms; during the Civil War, Dix proposed a plan to the war department to establish a volunteer corps of women nurses. This allowed her to be appointed as superintendent of women nurses for the Union Army in June of 1861. Realizing she was ill-suited for the job, Dix resigned her position and returned to work with institutions. After the war, she proceeded to raise funds for over 50 hospitals that she had previously helped establish. In 1881, Dorothea Dix retired to one of the institutions she helped found, Trenton State Hospital, New Jersey.

Dix’s Impact After Death

People such as Marjorie Lehman O’Rorke continued to document the impact that Dix’s work had. According to O’Rorke’s book Haven on the Hill: A History of North Carolina’s Dorothea Dix Hospital, Dix endorsed a healthy, cheerful, and engaging environment rather than the mistreatment the mentally ill underwent. Dorothea Dix allowed changes such as the separation of less-ill patients from the more dangerous, the professionalism of nurses and more humane treatment for both prisoners and the mentally ill. Dix’s work on the development of mental health institutions became the birthplaces of psychiatry and essential to the training of mental health care providers.
